topic_text: Includes individual's feelings of satisfaction with life, whether they feel the things they do in their life are worthwhile and their positive and negative emotions.
text: Just under 3 in 10 people in the UK (29.3%) reported a very high rating of satisfaction with their lives overall in the year ending September 2016. While there was no overall change since the previous year (29.1%), there has been an improvement based on three years previously (26.5%).

In the year ending September 2016, 34.6% of people in the UK reported a very high rating that the things they do were worthwhile. There was no overall change since the year ending September 2015 (34.5%) but an improvement over a three year period (32.1%).

In the year ending September 2016, 34.4% of people in the UK reported their happiness yesterday as very high. While this has remained unchanged compared to year ending September 2015 (34.2%), there has been an improvement over the long term basis (31.8% in year ending September 2013).

In the year ending September 2016, 40.4% of people in the UK rated their anxiety as very low. This has fallen since the year previous (41.3%), but has shown an improvement over the long term basis (39.1% in year ending September 2013).

In 2012 to 2013, the average rating of positive mental well-being in the UK was 24.6 out of 35. While change was not assessed over the 1 year period, there was a deterioration over the 3 year period (25.2 out of 35 in 2009 to 2010).

topic_text: Positive relationships have one of the biggest impacts on our quality of life and happiness. This domain includes satisfaction with personal relationships and feelings of loneliness.
text: 8.4% of people in the UK stated they were fairly or extremely unhappy with their relationship in 2013 to 2014. While there was no change between the previous year, there has been an overall increase in those reporting being in unhappy relationships over the 3 year period.

The proportion of people in England who reported feelings of loneliness often or always was 4.1% in the year ending March 2016. There was no overall change from the previous year (4.1%), while the measure was not assessed over the 3 year period.

In 2013 to 2014, 84% of people in the UK reported having someone to rely on if they had a serious problem. This has fallen over the three year period with 86.1% reporting they had someone to rely on in 2010 to 2011.

topic_text: An individual's health is recognised as an important component of their well-being. This domain contains both subjective and objective measures of physical and mental health.
text: The healthy life expectancy at birth for males and females in the UK in 2013 to 2015 was 63.1 and 63.9 years respectively. This represented no overall change since 2011 to 2013 for both males (62.9) and females (63.7). There was an improvement since 2009 to 2011 for males (62.7) and no overall change for females (63.9).
17.7% of people aged between 16 and 64 reported they had an illness or disability in Oct - Dec 2016, compared to 17.3% in the same period in the previous year. This change has not been assessed.

In 2014 to 2015, 49.6% of people in the UK were mostly or completely satisfied with their health. This was an improvement both from the previous year (44.6%) and over the 3 year period (45.4% in 2011 to 2012).

In 2014 to 2015, 17.3% of people in the UK showed some evidence of anxiety or depression. This was an improvement both from the previous year (19.7%) and over the 3 year period (18.8% in 2011 to 2012).

topic_text: Includes work and leisure activities and the balance between them.
text: There was no overall change in the unemployment rate in the UK between the 3 months ending January 2017 (4.7%) and the 3 months ending January 2016 (5.1%). While there was an improvement over the 3 year period (7.2% in the 3 months ending January 2014).

Over half of people in the UK (55.8%) were mostly or completely satisfied with their job in 2014 to 2015. This was an improvement both from the previous year's data (53.0%) and over the 3 year period (54.1% in 2011 to 2012).

The proportion of people in the UK who were mostly or completely satisfied with their amount of leisure time was 43.7% in 2014 to 2015, a improvement from the previous year (40.0%) and over the 3 year period (40.4% in 2011 to 2012).

Almost 1 in 5 people in the UK (19.1%) reported that they had participated in some kind of volunteering more than once in the last year in 2014 to 2015. This was an improvement from the previous year (17.4%) from 2010 to 2011 (16.7%).

In the year ending March 2016, just over 8 in 10 people in England (82.1%) had participated in an arts or cultural activity at least 3 times in the past year. This has remained unchanged on both the one year and three year basis (82.4% and 83.1% respectively.

In the year ending September 2016, 36.1% of people in England participated in 30 minutes of moderate intensity sport, once per week. While there was no overall change since the previous year (35.8%) there was a deterioration over the 3 year period (36.6% in the year ending September 2013).

topic_text: Reflects an individual's dwelling, their local environment and the type of community in which they live. Measures include having a safe, clean and pleasant environment, access to facilities and being part of a cohesive community.
text: In the year ending March 2016, there were an estimated 56 personal crimes per 1,000 adults (aged 16 and over) in England and Wales. There was no overall change since the year ending March 2015 (57 crimes per 1,000 adults) however, there has been an improvement over the 3 year period (75 crimes per 1,000 adults in the year ending March 2013).

In the year ending March 2016, 87.9% of men and 61.7% of women in England and Wales reported that they felt fairly or very safe walking alone after dark. While there has been an improvement over the long term basis (84.7% and 56.7% in the year ending March 2013 respectively), there was no change with the previous year (85.8% and 61.7% in the year ending March 2015 respectively).

Nearly 6 in 10 people in the UK (58.9%) visited the natural environment at least once a week in the 12 months prior to interview in the year ending March 2015. There was no overall change from the previous year (57.6%) and an improvement over the 3 year period (54.9% in the year ending March 2012).

The proportion of people in the UK who agreed or agreed strongly they felt they belonged to their neighbourhood in 2014 to 2015 was 68.8%. While change was not assessed over the 1 year period, there was an improvement over the 3 year period (63.3% 2011 to 2012).

The average minimum travel time by public transport or walking to an average of 8 main services was 17.0 minutes in England in 2014. As there is only 1 data point at present, the measure has not been assessed.

Just under 9 in 10 people in England (89.9%) were satisfied with their accommodation in the year ending March 2015. While there was no overall change since the previous year (89.2%) there was a deterioration over the 3 year period (91.2% in the year ending March 2012).

topic_text: Includes household income and wealth, its distribution and stability.
text: In the year ending March 2016 the proportion of individuals living in households with less than 60% of median income before housing costs was 16%. There was no overall change in both the 1 year period (16%) and the 3 year period (15% in the year ending March 2013).
In 2012/14 the median wealth per household, including pension wealth was £225,100, compared to £216,500 in 2010/12. This change has not been assessed.
Real median household income was £26,332 in the UK in the year ending March 2016, an improvement over the 1 year period (£25,768) and over the 3 year period (£24,137).

In 2014 to 2015, 42.8% of people in the UK were mostly or completely satisfied with the income of their household. This was an improvement both from the previous year's data (36.8%) and over the 3 year period (34.0% in 2011 to 2012).

In 2014 to 2015, 6.6% of people in the UK were reporting finding it quite or very difficult to get by financially.This was an improvement both from the previous year's data (9.1%) and over the 3 year period (10.9% in 2011 to 2012).

topic_text: Provides an important contextual domain for national well-being and includes measures of inflation and public sector debt.
text: The real net national disposable income per head in the UK was £24,244 in 2016, an improvement from the previous year (£23,890) and over the 3 year period (£22,986 in 2013)
In 2016, public sector net debt stood at 86.0% of GDP, compared with 84.7% in 2015. This change has not been assessed.
In 2016 the rate of inflation was 1.0%, compared to 0.4% a year earlier. This change has not been assessed.

topic_text: Includes aspects of education and the stock of human capital in the labour market with some more information about levels of educational achievement and skills.
text: In 2015, the value of full human capital amounted to £19.90 trillion. This was an improvement both from the previous year's data (£19.08 trillion) and over the 3 year period (£18.85 trillion in 2012).

The percentage of all young people in the UK who were NEET was 11.5% in October to December 2016. While there was no overall change since the previous year (11.9%) there was an improvement over the 3 year period (14.2% in October to December 2013).
In 2016, 8.1% of UK residents had no qualifications, an improvement over the 1 year period (8.7%) and over the 3 year period (9.3%).
Voter turnout at the UK general election was 66.2% in 2015, an improvement on 2010 (65.1%) and 2005 (61.4%).

In the autumn of 2016, 35% of people aged 15 and over in the UK reported that they 'tended to trust' their national government. This was an improvement on the previous year (31%) and over the 3 year period (24% in 2013).

topic_text: Reflects areas such as climate change, the natural environment and the effects our activities have on the global environment.
text: The UK's greenhouse gas emissions were estimated at 495.75 million tonnes carbon dioxide equivalent (MtCO2e) in 2015. This has decreased both on a one year (515.13 MtCO2e) and on a 3 year basis (575.24 MtCO2e in 2012).

In the UK in 2015, 21.4 million hectares of land and sea was designated as a nationally or internationally important protected area. While there was no overall change since the previous year (21.4 million hectares) there was an improvement over the 3 year period (14.50 million hectares in 2012).
8.3% of energy consumption came from renewable sources in 2015. This has improved over both the short term (7.1% in 2014) and the long term (4.6% in 2012)
There has been a decline in the proportion of household waste that was recycled between 2014 and 2015 (44.9% and 44.3% respectively).
